items.title: AWS: Adding a Layer to AWS Lambda in Node.js
items.content:encoded:
AWS Lambda layers are a powerful way to manage and share code and dependencies across multiple Lambda functions. They allow you to package libraries, custom runtimes, and other dependencies separately from your function code. This can help reduce deployment package sizes and promote codeÂ reuse.

In this blog post, we will walk through the steps to create a Lambda layer, add it to a Lambda function, and use it in a Node.js environment.

Prerequisites

  • AWS Account
  • AWS CLI configured
  • Node.js installed
  • Basic knowledge of AWS Lambda andÂ Node.js

Step 1: Create a LambdaÂ Layer

First, letâ€™s create a Lambda layer that includes a Node.js library. For this example, weâ€™ll use the axiosÂ library.

Create a directory for theÂ layer:

mkdir lambda-layer
cd lambda-layer

Initialize a Node.jsÂ project:

npm init -y

Install the axiosÂ library:

npm install axios

Create a nodejs directory and move the node_modules and package.json files intoÂ it:

mkdir nodejs
mv node_modules package.json nodejs/

Zip the nodejs directory:

zip -r layer.zip nodejs

Step 2: Create a LambdaÂ Function

Now that we have our layer, letâ€™s create a Lambda function and add the layer toÂ it.

Create a new directory for the Lambda function:

mkdir lambda-function
cd lambda-function

Create an index.js file with the following content:

const axios = require('axios');

exports.handler = async (event) => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.get('https://api.github.com/');
        return {
            statusCode: 200,
            body: JSON.stringify(response.data),
        };
    } catch (error) {
        return {
            statusCode: 500,
            body: JSON.stringify(error.message),
        };
    }
};

Zip the Lambda function:

zip -r function.zip index.js

Create the Lambda function using the AWSÂ CLI:

aws lambda create-function \
--function-name myLambdaFunction \
--runtime nodejs14.x \
--role arn:aws:iam::YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID:role/YOUR_LAMBDA_EXECUTION_ROLE \
--handler index.handler \
--zip-file fileb://function.zip

Replace YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID and YOUR_LAMBDA_EXECUTION_ROLE with your actual AWS account ID and Lambda execution roleÂ ARN.

Step 3: Add the Layer to the LambdaÂ Function

Retrieve the Layer VersionÂ ARN:

After publishing the layer, you will get a response containing the LayerVersionArn. It will look something likeÂ this:

{
  "LayerVersionArn": "arn:aws:lambda:us-west-2:123456789012:layer:axios-layer:1",
  ...
}

Add the layer to your Lambda function:

aws lambda update-function-configuration \
--function-name myLambdaFunction \
--layers arn:aws:lambda:us-west-2:123456789012:layer:axios-layer:1

Step 4: Test the LambdaÂ Function

You can test your Lambda function using the AWS Management Console or the AWSÂ CLI.

Invoke the function using the AWSÂ CLI:

aws lambda invoke --function-name myLambdaFunction output.txt

Check theÂ output:

cat output.txt

You should see the response from the GitHubÂ API.

Conclusion

This should give you a comprehensive guide on how to add a layer to AWS Lambda in Node.js. If you have any questions or run into issues, feel free toÂ comment!

Happy coding!

items.title: Binary Search 1
items.content:encoded:
Binary search divides search space into two parts based on some intermediate results during the search this reduces the time complexity of the search problem. But, the underlying assumption is that search space should beÂ sorted.

In this article, some problems share some common concepts in their solution.

Consider a situation in which an array is sorted in ascending order. The array can have repeated values also. Here aim is to find the given target in thisÂ array.

Problem 1: Finding the target in the array using binaryÂ search.

Problem 2: Finding the first and last occurrences of the target in anÂ array.

Problem 3: Finding the insertion position of the target if it is notÂ present.

Solution 1: Remove the search space where the chance of finding the target isÂ zero.

Solution 2: Once the target element is found and it is possible that it can have multiple occurrences then continue searching in the left search space for the first occurrence and searching in the right search space for the last occurrence. Remember to record the latest occurrence of the target each time you findÂ it.

Solution 3: The pointer representing the left search space signifies that all numbers before the left or start pointer are smaller than the target. After traversing the whole search space with no target found the left or pointer signifies that all numbers before the last left or start pointer position are smaller than the target. The current position of the left pointer will be the insertion position for the target. If the last position of the left or start position is more than the maximum allowable index then the insertion position of the target is imaginary but a validÂ answer.

Below is the combined code for all the above solutions.

class Solution {
    private static class BsResponse {
        private boolean isElementPresent;
        private int index;

        public BsResponse(boolean isElementPresent, int index) {
            this.isElementPresent = isElementPresent;
            this.index = index;
        }

        public boolean isElementPresent() {
            return isElementPresent;
        }

        public int getIndex() {
            return index;
        }
    }

    private static class BsRequest {
        enum Option {
            ANY_OCCURRENCE, FIRST_OCCURRENCE, LAST_OCCURRENCE,
        }

        private int[] arr;
        private int target;
        private int start;
        private int end;
        private Option option;

        public BsRequest(int[] arr, int target, int start, int end, Option option) {
            this.arr = arr;
            this.target = target;
            this.start = start;
            this.end = end;
            this.option = option;
        }

        public int[] getArr() {
            return arr;
        }

        public int getTarget() {
            return target;
        }

        public int getStart() {
            return start;
        }

        public int getEnd() {
            return end;
        }

        public Option getOption() {
            return option;
        }
    }

    private static BsResponse binarySearch(BsRequest request) {

        int[] arr = request.getArr();
        int target = request.getTarget();
        int start = request.getStart();
        int end = request.getEnd();
        BsRequest.Option option = request.getOption();

        boolean isElementPresent = false;
        int index = -1;
        while (start <= end) {
            int mid = start + (end - start) / 2;
            if (arr[mid] < target) {
                start = mid + 1;
            } else if (arr[mid] > target) {
                end = mid - 1;
            } else {
                isElementPresent = true;
                index = mid;
                if (option.equals(BsRequest.Option.LAST_OCCURRENCE)) {
                    start = mid + 1;
                } else if (option.equals(BsRequest.Option.FIRST_OCCURRENCE)) {
                    end = mid - 1;
                } else if (option.equals(BsRequest.Option.ANY_OCCURRENCE)) {
                    break;
                }
            }
        }
        return new BsResponse(isElementPresent, isElementPresent ? index : start);
    }

    private static void printAnswer(boolean isElementPresent, int target, int index) {
        if (isElementPresent) {
            System.out.println("Index of last occurrence of " + target + " is: " + index);
        } else {
            System.out.println("Insertion position of " + target + " is: " + index);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] arr = {1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3, 5};
        int x = 2;
        //solution
        int n = arr.length;
        BsRequest request_1 = new BsRequest(arr, x, 0, n - 1, BsRequest.Option.FIRST_OCCURRENCE);
        BsResponse result_1 = binarySearch(request_1);
        printAnswer(result_1.isElementPresent, x, result_1.index);

        BsRequest request_2 = new BsRequest(arr, x, 0, n - 1, BsRequest.Option.LAST_OCCURRENCE);
        BsResponse result_2 = binarySearch(request_2);
        printAnswer(result_2.isElementPresent, x, result_2.index);

        x = 4;
        BsRequest request_3 = new BsRequest(arr, x, 0, n - 1, BsRequest.Option.ANY_OCCURRENCE);
        BsResponse result_3 = binarySearch(request_3);
        printAnswer(result_3.isElementPresent, x, result_3.index);
    }
}

items.title: [Blind 2] Counting Bits
items.content:encoded:
This blog is part of a blog series of Blind 75 coding problems and their solutions. Please get the list of all blind 75 problemsÂ here.

Please read the problem statement and try to solve it before reading the solution.

Approach 1

Calculate the number of â€˜1â€™ s from the bit representation of a number from 0 toÂ n.

Code for approachÂ 1

class Solution {
public:
    int getHammingWeight(int n) {
        int count = 0;
        while (n) {
            count++;
            n &= n - 1;
        }
        return count;
    }
    vector<int> countBits(int n) {
        vector<int> ans;
        for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) {
            ans.push_back(getHammingWeight(i));
        }
        return ans;
    }
};

Time complexity: O(nlogn)

Space complexity: O(n)

Approach 2

Let us write a bit representation of numbers from 0 toÂ 16.

One simple observation is that at every power value of 2, we are making the right-most bit â€˜1â€™ and other bitsÂ â€˜0â€™.

Consider numbers from 8 to 13, remove the right-most bit, and observe the newÂ numbers.

Do we know the number of â€˜1â€™ s in new numbers? Not sure. But, we can get the number of â€˜1â€™ s in the bit representation of numbers from 8 to 13 by adding 1 with the number of â€˜1â€™ s in the bit representation of new numbers i.e. count_1[8] = 1 + count_1[0], count_1[9] = 1 + count_1[1] and soÂ on.

At every power of 2, the new number will be 0. And, the next number will be the (number-latest power of 2). All these observations can be concluded in the following image.

This dynamic programming technique.

count[n] = 1 + count[n-offset]

where the offset is the latest power ofÂ 2.

code for approachÂ 2

class Solution {
public:
    vector<int> countBits(int n) {
        vector<int> ans(n + 1, 0);
        int offset = 1;
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            if (offset * 2 == i) {
                offset *= 2;
            }
            ans[i] = ans[i - offset] + 1;
        }
        return ans;
    }
};

Time complexity: O(n)

Space complexity: O(n)

items.title: [Blind 1] Number of one-bits
items.content:encoded:
This blog is part of a blog series of Blind 75 coding problems and their solutions. Please get the list of all blind 75 problemsÂ here.

Please read the problem statement and try to solve it before reading the solution.

Approach 1

Letâ€™s say the given number isÂ n,

  1. Find the right-most bit, if it is â€˜1â€™ countÂ it.
  2. Right shift (bitwise) number n by 1Â bit.
  3. Repeat step 1 and step 2 until number n is notÂ 0.

How to get the right-most bit? There are two ways to doÂ it.

  1. Take bitwise AND (&) of n withÂ â€˜1â€™.
  2. Divide n by 2, and the remainder will be theÂ answer.

How to right shift numberÂ n.

  1. Use the right shift operator >> (available in most coding languages).
  2. Divide n by 2, and the quotient will be theÂ answer.

Code for approachÂ 1.

class Solution {
public:
    int hammingWeight(uint32_t n) {
        int count = 0;
        while (n) {
            count += n % 2;
            n >>= 1;
        }
        return count;
    }
};

Time complexityÂ :Â O(1)

Space complexity: O(1)

Approach 2

  1. Subtract one from the number n to get rid of â€˜1â€™ from n, say the number isÂ n-1.
  2. Now, restore the remaining bits by AND operation between n andÂ n-1.
  3. Repeat step 1 and step 2 until n is notÂ zero.
  4. The total iteration count will be theÂ answer.

e.g. n = 1000010010

A good trick for quick implementation.

Code for approachÂ 2.

class Solution {
public:
    int hammingWeight(uint32_t n) {
        int count = 0;
        while (n) {
            count++;
            n &= n - 1;
        }
        return count;
    }
};

Time complexity: O(1)

Space complexity: O(1)

items.title: [Leetcode Hard 1] Nth Magical Number
items.content:encoded:
This article has a detailed solution to this LeetcodeÂ problem.

Question

A positive integer is magical if it is divisible by either a orÂ b.

Given the three integers n, a, and b, return the nth magical number. Since the answer may be very large, return it modulo 109 +Â 7.

Brute ForceÂ Approach

Start from 1 and count iterations till the nth magical number is achieved.

class Solution {
public:
    int mod = 1e9 + 7;

    int nthMagicalNumber(int n, int a, int b) {
        int k = min(a, b);
        int count = 0;
        while (count < n) {
            if (k % a == 0 || k % b == 0) {
                count++;
            }
            k++;
        }
        return (k - 1) % mod;
    }
};

Time Complexity: O(n)

Space Complexity: O(1)

The above code will result inÂ TLE.

Optimized Approach

The intuition behind the optimized approach

  1. The minimum number which is divisible by a or b is a minimum of a andÂ b.
  2. The maximum number that is divisible by a or b is a nth multiple of the minimum of a andÂ b.
  3. Between minimum and maximum numbers, all the numbers are sorted in increasing order.

There is a range that has sorted elements. The idea is binary search, but how to divide search space into twoÂ parts?

At any point, we can calculate the number of multiples of a or b. If at any number in the range (say K ), the count of multiples of a or b exceeds n then we can ignore search space greater than K else we can ignore search space less than K because we need the exact nth multiple of a or b. If at K, we get the count of multiples of a or b equal to n then we will check if K is a multiple of a or b our answer is K if K is not a multiple of a or b then we will move left because number of multiples is n, we will get our answer in left searchÂ space.

How to get the number of multiples of a or b at numberÂ K.

Count of multiples of a = K / a
Count of multiples of b = K / b
Count of multiples of LCM(a, b) = K / LCM(a, b)

Total count = K / a + K / b - K / LCM (a, b)

LCM(a, b) = a * b / HCF(a, b)

Letâ€™s test our approach.

Given n = 4, a = 2, b =Â 3

Multiples of 2 = 2, 4, 6, 8Â â€¦

Multiples of 3 = 3, 6, 9, 12Â â€¦

First 4 multiples of 2 or 3 = 2, 3, 4,Â 6

Our answer should beÂ 6.

class Solution {
public:
    int mod = 1e9 + 7;
    int getMultipleCount(long long num, int a, int b, int lcm) {
        return (num / a) + (num / b) - (num / lcm);
    }
    int getLcm(int a, int b) {
        int lcm = 0, hcf;
        int oA = a, oB = b;
        //hcf
        while (a != 0 && b != 0) {
            if (a > b) {
                a = a % b;
            }
            else {
                b = b % a;
            }
        }
        if (a == 0) {
            hcf = b;
        }
        else {
            hcf = a;
        }
        return (oA * oB) / hcf;
    }
    int nthMagicalNumber(int n, int a, int b) {
        long long left = min(a, b) * 1;
        long long right = (min((a * 1L), (b * 1L)) * (n * 1L));
        int lcm = getLcm(a, b);
        long long ans = right;
        while (left <= right) {
            long long mid = left + (right - left) / 2;
            int factorCount = getMultipleCount(mid, a, b, lcm);
            if (factorCount >= n) {
                if (factorCount == n && (mid % a == 0 || mid % b == 0)) {
                    ans = mid;
                    break;
                }
                else {
                    right = mid - 1;
                }
            }
            else {
                left = mid + 1;
            }
        }
        return ans % mod;
    }
};

Time complexity: O(log(min(a, b) * (nâ€Šâ€”â€Š1)))

Space complexity: O(1)

Thanks for reading. Waiting for valuable comments.

items.title: Find an overlapped area between two rectangles.
items.content:encoded:
The information in this article may be easy for many people but I am still explaining thisÂ problem.

This article is inspired by this LeetcodeÂ problem.

In this problem, two rectangles are given to find the total area covered by two rectangles. A rectangle here is represented by the bottom left corner and top right corner. The solution is simple, add the areas of two rectangles and subtract the common or overlapped area (if any) between these two rectangles, a simple union. It is easy to find areas of two rectangles but the probable confusion is how to find the common or overlapped area.

In this blog, we will find the common or overlapped area between two rectangles.

Refer above image for a better visual understanding of the problem and solution.

Problem

Given two rectangles in a two-dimensional plane A and B. A is represented by its bottom left corner A1(ax1, ay1) and top right corner A2(ax2, ay2). Similarly, B is represented by its bottom left corner B1(bx1, by1) and top right corner B2(bx2,Â by2).

Solution

The common area will be a rectangle overlapped by P, Q, S, and R. The problem will be solved if we can find the bottom left corner R and top right cornerÂ Q.

Finding the bottom left cornerÂ (R)

X coordinate of the corner R will be either ax1 or bx1. How to decide? Represent ax1 and bx1 on the horizontal number line, the larger value among ax1 and bx1 will decide the left starting boundary of the common area because the value that comes after the other will decide the starting boundary of the commonÂ area.

Similarly, for the Y coordinate of the corner R. Represent ay1 and by1 on the vertical number line, the larger value among ay1 and by1 will decide the bottom starting boundary of the commonÂ area.

R(x, y) = max(ax1, bx1), max(ay1,Â by1)

Finding the top right cornerÂ (Q)

X coordinate of the corner Q will be either ax2 or bx2. How to decide? Represent ax2 and bx2 on the horizontal number line, the smaller value among ax2 and bx2 will decide the right closing boundary of the common area because the value that comes before the other will decide the closing boundary of the commonÂ area.

Similarly, for the Y coordinate of the corner Q. Represent ay2 and by2 on the vertical number line, the smaller value among ay2 and by2 will decide the top closing boundary of the commonÂ area.

Q(x, y) = min(ax2, bx2), min(ay2,Â by2)

Now, that the coordinates of the bottom left corner (R) and top right corner (Q) of the common area are decided, we can easily calculate the commonÂ area.

Width of common area = max (Q(x)-R(x), 0)

Height of common area = max(Q(y)-R(y), 0)

We are taking the maximum of coordinate differences and zero because in case height or width are non-positive then the common area will notÂ exist.

Thanks for reading. Waiting for commentsÂ !!!

items.title: Customer Transaction Prediction using LightGBM
items.content:encoded:
Exploratory Data Analysis and modelling with imbalanced data using LightGBM.

I was learning Python for data analysis and wanted to apply the concepts on a real data setâ€Šâ€”â€Šthen I found thisÂ problem.

In this problem, we need to identify which customers will make a specific transaction in the future, irrespective of the amount of money transacted.

Training data is an anonymous data set containing 200 numeric feature variables, the binary target column, and a string ID_code column and 2,00,000 observations. Test data includes 200 anonymous numeric variables and a string ID_code column and 2,00,000 observations. This is a binary classification problem under supervised machine learning algorithm. The task is to predict the value of target column in the testÂ set.

In this article I will discuss what is general business significance of this problem? How to explore data? And how to built a Light GBM model for classification problem on imbalanced data with tuning of model parameters. Python code used for this article is here. Letâ€™s start this journeyÂ ðŸ‘‡.

General Business Significance

This project can help company in following ways-

1. Exploratory DataÂ Analysis

Exploratory data analysis mainly includes missing value analysis, outlier analysis, correlation analysis, descriptive analysis and visualizations to gain insights fromÂ data.

First Letâ€™s check the amount of minority and majority class in the trainingÂ data.

Minority class is almost 10% of target variable in trainÂ data.

Dealing with Imbalanced dataÂ set

Before modelling for this data set let us understand how to deal with imbalanced data set for classification problem. Traditional Machine Learning algorithms tend to produce unsatisfactory classifiers when faced with imbalanced data sets. For any imbalanced data set, if the event to be predicted belongs to the minority class and the event rate is less than 10%, it is usually referred to as a rare event. The conventional model evaluation methods do not accurately measure model performance when faced with imbalanced data sets. Standard classifier algorithms like Decision Tree and Logistic Regression have a bias towards classes which have large number of instances. They tend to only predict the majority class data. The features of the minority class are treated as noise and are often ignored. Thus, there is a high probability of mis-classification of the minority class as compared to the majority class. Performance of classification algorithm is measured by the Confusion Matrix which contains information about the actual and the predicted class. Thus we need to deal with this imbalanced dataÂ set.

Here are some methods to deal with imbalanced data for classification.

There is no missing values in both train and testÂ data.

Let us check the distribution of first 20 numerical features in train data by plotting histograms of each variable. (For distribution of complete features goÂ here.)

Looking at the shapes of histograms we can easily conclude that almost all numeric variables follow normal distribution.

I have decided to see if there are any outliers in the data set according to Chauvenetâ€™s criterion. After removing outliers (0.87% of total observations) we have 1,98,264 observations in train data and 1,98,250 observations in testÂ data.

Now letâ€™s check the distribution of first 20 variables in train data with both of the target classes. (For checking distribution of all variables goÂ here.)

From the above plots we can see that some variables show different distributions for different target classes. But using tree based algorithms can deal with these different distributions in target class because recovering 0 and 1 is exactly what a tree based classification model does. For each observation, a model can assign the probability that that observation belongs to 0 and the probability that that value belongs toÂ 1.

Distribution of first 20 numeric variables in the training and test data. (For complete distribution goÂ here.)

The train and test seems to be well balanced with respect to distribution of the numeric variables.

Visualizing class wise descriptive statistics such as meanÂ ,median, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, kurtosis and skewness of train data I plotted the following graphs. We can make a few observations here:

Standard deviation is relatively large for both training and test variable data. However, the min, max, mean, median, standard deviation values for training and test data looks quite close. Mean values are distributed over a large range. Moreover, mean and median have similar distribution. Both training and test data is Leptokurtic and negatively skewed.

Now checking correlation among numerical variables, minimum and maximum correlation among numerical variables in train data are -0.009839 and 0.009676 respectively. This shows that the correlations between the numerical data are close to zero. That means that most of the numerical data are almost uncorrelated betweenÂ them.

At this point I will go for Principal component analysis (PCA) to check whether all 200 variables are useful or we can reduce features at this point of time. For this I will plot the experienced variance obtained from PCA. If it forms a straight line with slope 1 then we can conclude that the data set have already gone with PCA. (Know more about PCAÂ here.)

Thus we have to go with all 200 features.

Feature Engineering

Add row wise descriptive statistics i.e. mean, median, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, kurtosis, skewness and sum as separate features in training data set. I created 200 new features based on the original 200 features where the new values for these new features would be the number of unique occurrences (frequency) of the value in each cell of a particular variable. Often there can be relevant information in the frequency, depending on how the categories are drawn. But we have to be cautious while adding features. We should check duplicate observations in both train and test data. There are 1,00,000 observations found which are duplicate in testÂ data.

Now I have 410 variables in the training data set and 409 in the test dataÂ set.

Before going for modelling letâ€™s have some stuff about the classification evaluation metric AUC-ROC Score (good understanding of confusion matrix is required.). It is one of the most important evaluation metrics for checking any classificationâ€™s performance. It is also written as AUC-ROC (Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristics). AUC-ROC curve is a performance measurement for classification problem at various thresholds settings. ROC is a probability curve and AUC represents degree or measure of separability. It tells how much model is capable of distinguishing between classes. Higher the AUC, the better the model is at predicting 0 as 0 and 1 as 1. The ROC curve is plotted with True Positive Rate (TPR) against the False Positive Rate (FPR) where TPR is on y-axis and FPR is on theÂ x-axis.

Why to use LightÂ GBM?

As we I discussed earlier in this article, our data set is imbalanced and thus we should not use traditional models like logistic regression. Idea about Naive Bayes is good but we should assure independence of predictor variables as we have almost uncorrelated predictor variables but that do not assure about independence betweenÂ them.

Light GBM builds trees one at a time, where each new tree helps to correct errors made by previously trained tree. It performs the optimization in function space (rather than in parameter space) which makes the use of custom loss functions much easier. It is also faster in speed and accuracy as compared to bagging and adaptive boosting. It is capable of performing equally good with large data sets with a significant reduction in training time as compared to XGBOOST. But along with these advantages there is most disadvantageous feature of LGBM i.e. parameter tuning in LightGBM. It should be done carefully. (Know more about Light GBM parameters.)

Modelling

After modelling with LightGBM with standard parameters, the AUC Score was 0.88576. After adding features and modelling with same standard parameters before modelling then I got AUC Score 0.89968. After tuning parameters and using K fold Stratified cross validation with k=10 I got AUC ScoreÂ 9.0600.

Precision Score for  LightGBM is  0.777291272763459
Recall Score for LightGBM is  0.39970320335687237
f1 Score for LightGBM is  0.527930789767159

Using Parallel Processing with LightGBM Algorithm.

Taking a try for XGBoost for fasterÂ speeds.

End Notes

This was a binary classification problem on a typically unbalanced data set with no missing values. Predictor variables are anonymous and numeric and target variable is categorical. Visualizing descriptive features and finally I got to know that these variables are not correlated among themselves. After that I decided to treat imbalanced data set. Modelling with LightGBM, using the standard model parameters with feature engineered data I got AUC-Score of 0.899 and after tuning parameters with K fold stratified sampling final value of AUC Score isÂ 0.90600.
